fields.description:
simply adding a changeset (quite small) to an existing review can take a lot of time.

A new-relic profile is available here: https://rpm.newrelic.com/accounts/9704/applications/294350/profiles/1363

It appears 64% is spent in 
64.0%  - com.cenqua.crucible.revision.source.RepositorySource.isOnAncestryLine
.

This means, for certain changesets, even with the suggest reviews taken out of the equation, adding a changeset to a review will still be far too slow.

e.g. The following changesets were added to a review on atlaseye in the CR-BAM project. Times next to each are included. Some are fast, others are up to 15s.

fields.summary: addChangeset for DVCS extremely slow

fields.description:
Is not possible to remove users from a review when using Internet Explorer. The remove button simply does not shows up.

Replicable with IE8.
When using Chrome 22 and FF 15 everything works just fine.
fields.summary: Is not possible to remove users from a review when using Internet Explorer 8

fields.description:
From http://mercurial.selenic.com/wiki/GitExtendedDiffFormat

    Mercurial's default format for showing changes between two
    versions of a file is compatible with the unified format of GNU
    diff, which can be used by GNU patch and many other standard
    tools.

    While this standard format is often enough, it does not encode the
    following information:

     - executable status and other permission bits
     - copy or rename information
     - changes in binary files
     - creation or deletion of empty files

    Mercurial also supports the extended diff format from the git VCS
    which addresses these limitations. The git diff format is not
    produced by default because a few widespread tools still do not
    understand this format.



Crucible is one of the "few widespread tools" that does not support the extended git diffs.
fields.summary: Add Support For Mercurial Patches Using Git Extended Diff Format

fields.description:
CodeCollaborator and many software diff engines allow for the synchronized horizontal scrolling of in side-by-side diff mode. Many of our sight-impaired engineers who balk at the over-under paradigm are complaining that Crucible's side-by-side view does not offer:
# Synchronized horizontal scrolling
# Single page real-estate layout (nebulous view there)
Please offer this view as a single screen layout with synced horizontal scrolling.
fields.summary: Please implement synchronized horizontal side-by-side diff scrolling

fields.description:
Every now and then I would like to add praise/well done comments in reviews. I can now add them as regular comments but it would be nice to be able to promote comments as thank you's as defects can be marked as ... well ... defects.

These morale boosting comments should be searchable as defects and regular comments are now.
fields.summary: Mark review comment as 'well done'

fields.description:
I'm trying to match related issues from the title of the
Crucible review which is sth like: "AURORA-132:....."

Below REST API call fails to search for "AURORA-558" string inside reviews' titles and return all results containing either AURORA or 558.

/usr/bin/curl --silent -H 'Content-Type: application/xml' -X GET -u xxx:xxx 'http://rdreview:8060/crucible/rest-service/reviews-v1/filter?title=AURORA-558&author=gunesar&states=Review' |xmllint --format -

Is there any way to find all titles containing AURORA-558 in their titles ?
fields.summary: Cannot use hypen with REST API filter queries

fields.description:
We'd like the ability to notify specific reviewers about comments that are posted on files instead of sending out notification to every reviewer.

Specifically we'd like to be able to make it so that notification for comments only get sent to reviewers who are listed as either the original submitter or someone who's since modified the file in the respository.  One of our groups found that many of their reviewers were complaining about the large volume of emails about comments unrelated to file they were working on.  Given the difficulty of trying to break down reviews to individuals or two person groups, they were hoping that an option like this on a review would allow them to limit the number of unnecessary notifications.
fields.summary: Sending notifications to sub-set of reviewers

fields.description:
When we are attempting to add changesets to an existing review we choose to Edit Details, and are getting a server error when the details page loads. If we close it and choose to add content, we get another error (in firefox) or a spinner that goes on forever (in Chrome).

This is making Crucible completely unusable.
fields.summary: Unable to add changesets

fields.description:
If I come to a file which FishEye thinks is binary, I should be
able, right in the UI, to tell FishEye to ignore what it thinks and
treat the file as text (or vice versa - although less common).
fields.summary: Handling binary files (a.k.a. overriding current indexed content)

fields.description:
Docs say in 2.2 1.b. 

bq. Click 'Edit' in the section titled 'JIRA or Crowd Authentication'.

There is no such section for a fresh install of Crucible without JIRA or Crowd configured. See screenshots.

And to make matters worse, if LDAP settings are already configured, users first need to *Remove* them - also worth noting in the docs.
fields.summary: Update incorrect JIRA Integration docs

fields.description:
Customer called and he reported that he was unable to enter the new FISHEYE license key he has just purchased. He reported an error message "Invalid CRUCIBLE license key" and the FishEye license key was not accepted.

It turned out that he has in fact copied a valid Fisheye License key in the Fisheye License field. But he did not install a Crucible demo license key in his test period. Therefore, the Crucible license field contained the string "disabled", which was interpreted as an invalid license key, hence the error message.

Solution: if the Crucible license field contains the string "disabled", it should be ignored as a license key.
fields.summary: Confusing licensing related error message

fields.description: When doing Crucible code review, it would be nice to be able to attach an HTML file (such as a report) that is not treated as code to be reviewed but as a document with information pertinent to the review.
fields.summary: When doing crucible code review, it would be nice to be able to attach an HTML file (such as a report) that is not treated as code to be reviewed but as a document with information pertinent to the review

fields.description:
Created from https://support.atlassian.com/browse/CRC-4300
----

Reviewer should be able to toggle an OK/KO state for their reviews to indicate whether or not they're happy with the review.

That status is independent from the completion of the review. In other terms the following combinations are possible:

- Completed + OK
- Completed + KO
- Uncomplete + OK
- Uncomplete + KO

When thinking about this feature we should as well think of a +1/-1 system which would give an overall score to the review. It might be better than a single status per reviewer.

The original issue was that for a reviewer you can get a lot of noise in the reviews columns if you have reviews that are pending modifications from the author of the changes.
fields.summary: Have an OK/KO status on reviews

fields.description:
Go to an open review page, the label at the top left says " ... (due in X days)".
Click Edit review, change Due Date.
The Edit dialog closes but the "due in" is still X days.
fields.summary: "due in X days/weeks" label at the top left of the review page should be updated asynchronously after user changes Due date.

fields.description:
After deleting a user, ran a reindex on Crucible and ensured they are no longer listed under "Users" screen in "Administration" and not counted towards the license limit. 
Created a new Review and could see and select the deleted user from the user lookup for Reviewer and Moderator role in Crucible reviews.
fields.summary: Deleted users are appearing in reviewer, moderator dropdown

fields.description:
The Crucible review screen also displays previous commit numbers and author of other users in the line margins, as can be seen in the attached image.

Those previous author names, and lines may confuse some users. So it should have a way to omit all usernames other than the author inside the review screen.

fields.description:
I have discovered that "smart commit" feature does not work in Crucible without FishEye licence - I may be wrong but as this feature is documented in FishEye, it seams to be an educated guess.

So I propose to disable administrative screens that are related to FishEye licence when it is not enabled. So "smart commit", probably "web hooks" or any other I may not be aware of.
fields.summary: Hide admin screens for disabled feature when FishEye is not licenced.

fields.summary: Missing Attachment Upload Item's cause NullPointerException when viewing a Review which has inline comments on the missing attachment

fields.description:
*Premisses:*
* Crucible 2.7.10
* User logged in, and has {{View}} permission on a Crucible project

*Problem:*
If I go to {{Projects}} menu, select a project, it'll show the {{Activity}} tab and list the activity on that project as expected:
!Screenshot1.jpg!

I can also click on a review ID listed on the Activy Stream, and it'll open the review without any issues.

However, if I click on the {{Reviews}} tab, right next to the {{Activity}} tab, it'll show this:
!Screenshot2.jpg!

If I click on the browser's {{Back}} button, the previous screen shows up (oh really??), but the interesting fact is that *the user is still logged in*. I hit F5 to double check this.

The logs with extra debugging are attached.
fields.summary: NPE when trying to access Reviews tab in Crucible

fields.description: Crucible is not sending notifications when reviews have no title but no error message is displayed inside log files. However once a title is added to the review all notifications are automatically sent, even those related to anciet changes.
fields.summary: Crucible is not sending notifications when Review have no title.

fields.description:
This affects the just released 2.8.0--this isn't available on the affects version list btw.

Prior to this version upgrade, submodules were not supported but they at least didn't produce a GUI error. Now it does.

I can't completely exclude the Submodules since some changesets mix submodule changes along with file changes.

Please help silent swallow this error...or better yet, show the submodule hash diff.

Thanks!

RBC Growth Deck

fields.description:
Crucible seems to have a problem when creating a review from a squashed commit. The problem seems to be in the way that the file history does not always match the actual commit history. This can happen e.g when commits are squashed or ammended.

Lets assume this is the history before a branch gets squashed:

{code}
commit 7bf9e8db <--- Head of feature branch
commit b16e2279
commit 8ebf05c1 <--- Last time timezonehelper.cpp was changed
commit 17f63d56
commit d9e23b98
commit 782d0970
commit bc18964f
commit aa1abe58 <--- Added timezonehelper.cpp
commit 72b554af
commit e8405008 <--- Branch point
{code}

In this example a file timezonehelper.cpp was added while working on the branch.
New commits where always pushed to the remote repository, i.e. indexed by Fisheye.

After the branch got squashed, the history looks like that:

{code}
commit 486d6bf7 <--- Head of feature branch
commit e8405008 <--- Branch point
{code}

The git log for the squashed commit contains the information tha the new file has 143 new lines:

{code}
....
 ................./timezonehelper.cpp     | 143 ++++
....
{code}

If I create a review for the commit 486d6bf7 (screen1.png) the following happens:

The file timezonehelper.cpp is shown ad 'Added', but the file historys used in the review is between the squashed commit (486) and the commit where the file was edited the last time before the squash (8eb). Since the file isn't different between 486 and 8eb 'No change' is shown. I.e. the file is just shown as empty file with no changes although the file has content.

Expected:
  * The full content of the file should be shown.
  * The file history should be between 486 and e84 (the previous commit in the history).

This happens for all new files that have been added while working on the feature branch.
fields.summary: Improve handling of squashed commits

fields.description:
When making smart commits like:

- ' This commit is for issue TEST-7 and want to create a review +review CR-TEST-6' 

It does not create a review using the *+review*. And the code parse the commit message incorrectly matching the *TEST-6* within the review ID in *CR-TEST-6* 

Because a part of it matches existing valid JIRA issue IDs, it is being added to the source tab of the unrelated jira issue.

Please check the attached screenshot.
fields.summary: Issue keys contained in review keys are incorrectly parsed in smart commits...

fields.description:
Nowadays while diffing file revisions in a review, Crucible will always show added (in green) and deleted (in red) lines of code.

There should be a way of hiding deleted lines of code.
fields.summary: Crucible review should allow to hide deleted lines of code

fields.description:
We have identified and fixed a vulnerability in FishEye and Crucible that results from behaviour of certain third-party frameworks used in FishEye and Crucible. This vulnerability allows any attacker to:

* Set the FishEye and Crucible instance to allow anonymous access
* Set the FishEye and Crucible instance to allow anonymous signup

All versions of FishEye and Crucible up to and including 2.7.14 are affected by this vulnerability. The vulnerability is fixed in FishEye and/or Crucible 2.8.0 and later.

Details of this vulnerability are available in the advisory at https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/FishEye+and+Crucible+Security+Advisory+2012-08-21

and https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE/FishEye+and+Crucible+Security+Advisory+2012-08-21
fields.summary: Crucible privilege escalation vulnerability

fields.description:
If a user adds a revision to a current code review, it will also display changes made by other users in a particular file both people were working in.

For Example:
UserA starts a review and some updates need to be made to FileA.
UserB is working in FileA as well and commits an update before UserA.
UserA commits his changes for FileA and updates the code review (by going to Add Content)
UserA will see both his changes and UserB’s changes in his review of FileA.

Since the workflow of this example permits branching for builds and not for underlined tasks an option to highlight only the changes made by the person updating the review from the picked changeset, i.e. "Show My Changes Only", would be greatly received.
fields.summary: Distinguish file revisions by user
'Resource not found' Error in Review Coverage Gadget

fields.description:
In the following use case:
1. Create a Crucible review for a file/revision on a *Forked Repository*
2. Once the review was Closed, merge the *Forked Repository* reviewed file/revision to the *Original Repository*
3. Crucible will not know that the code was already reviewed and in the *Original Repository* will track it as "not reviewed".

Since the code was already reviewed in the Fork, would be good to have Crucible showing it as already reviewed in the Original repo as well.

By opening the "Original Repository" review, a review of the "Forked" would be displayed.

Currently, the only Fork feature in FeCru is the following:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Forking+Git+Repositories
fields.summary: Provide DVCS fork tracking in order to avoid duplicated reviews for the same code

fields.description:
Is it possible to be able to sort by JIRA priority on the Crucible Review Dashboard?

We have some JIRA issues that have HOTFIX or CRITICAL priority.  After a review has been created for high priority JIRA issues, there doesn't seem to be a way to indicate that the review for these issues should be reviewed first.  Also, there doesn't appear to be a way to search by the JIRA issue priority in Crucible. 

It would save time and add huge value if we could list the reviews by JIRA issue priority.   As one of our reviewers noted, when he looks at his Crucible Inbox in the morning he has no way of telling if a review is related to a high priority issue.  His main complaint is that he has to open each review, then switch over to JIRA to see if the issue has a high priority.
fields.summary: List reviews by JIRA priority on Crucible Review Dashboard

fields.description:
Hello there.

I have received this information from a customer and opened this JAC:

{quote}When reviewing sourcecode files, we need find the contextual information.

*For example:* when I review a file, I find a variable or function name, I need known where it was defined, something like SourceInsight or Eclipse IDE, it can jump to the location of variable defination by clicking the name of function or variable.{quote}

Thank you in advance.

Cheers,
*Douglas Fabretti*
*Atlassian Support*
fields.summary: Finding the contextual information When reviewing sourcecode files

fields.description:
*Premises:*
Three users involved:
* {{User 1}} as Author & Moderator
* {{User 2}} as Reviewer
* {{User 3}} as Reviewer

*Steps to reproduce:*
# Logged in with {{User 1}}
# Created a new review this way:
** {{Browse Changesets}} and chose one of the changesets listed
** Clicked {{Edit Details}}, added {{User 2}} and {{User 3}} as reviewers
** Clicked {{Start Review}}
# Review {{CR-1}} was created, and {{User 2}} and {{User 3}} were displaying {{Reviewer - 0% complete}} under {{Role}} column
# Logged out and logged in as {{User 2}}
# Accessed {{CR-1}}
# Opened a file on the left hand side to see (and only see) its code
# Clicked on {{General Comments}} link on the left hand side of the screen
# {{User 2}} is now displaying {{Reviewer - 100% complete}} under {{Role}} column. {{User 3}} is still displaying {{Reviewer - 0% complete}} under {{Role}} column
# Logged out and logged in as {{User 3}}
# Accessed {{CR-1}}
# Opened a file on the left hand side to see (and only see) its code
# Clicked on {{General Comments}} link on the left hand side of the screen
# {{User 2}} and {{User 3}} are now displaying {{Reviewer - 100% complete}} under {{Role}} column, and I did nothing but clicked on the {{General Comments}} link
fields.summary: Review status changing automatically to 100%

fields.description:
Hi, our users do pre-commit reviews (a lot) and we need to be able to kick off a review from a JIRA issue...before we have the code committed to SVN/GIT.  So there is no way to use the JIAR Source tab to start a review in Crucible.  

JIRA should have a button or "More Action" called "Add Review" or something similar that starts a draft review in Crucible automatically linked back to this JIRA issue being viewed in JIRA.

There should be _no_ requirement to use the source tab, since no code is committed to SVN/GIT yet..its a pre-commit.
fields.summary: Create Crucible Review _without_ source tab

fields.description:
The time spent field should not be editable.

Can click on the time spent and change it to any time without actually spending that amount of time on the code review.
fields.summary: Time spent field in the Code Review is editable

fields.description:
The email notification when somebody starts a review and includes you on it as a reviewer is awkwardly phrased. 

The subject should really be something like - "You have been added to review CR-STASH-9999" instead of "State changed to Review: (CR-STASH-9999)"

The body could be reworked as well

"The state of CR-STASH-9999 has been changed:
Adam Ahmed changed it to Review"

Could be written much simpler. 
"Adam Ahmed started review CR-STASH-9999 and added you as a reviewer"
fields.summary: "State changed to Review" is an awkward way of saying someone started a review

fields.description: When passwords are changed or the authentication to a repo start failing, notify the FeCru Admins ao that the problem can be fixed as soon as possible.
fields.summary: Notify Administrators if authentication to repositories start failing

fields.description:
Atlassian products are great. We particularly like how reviewing source code works in Crucible.  And Bonfire lets your create JIRA issue from your web page and templates let you fill in field values.  You can also add remarks like "1 bird is too yellow." 

What would a great feature to have in Crucible is ability to work with rendered HTML pages in the source page so we can be detecting and addressing problems with out HTML prior to release.
fields.summary: Ability to review HTML code displayed on the Crucible browser as you do source code

fields.description: I would like to request a feature to allow you add a category to the Project list. Like Jira, we will have a lot of Projects that will be maintained in Crucible.. We can limit who can see what projects through the permissions(or can we?), however if a user has access to multiple business unit Projects I would like to see a Category or Group to help lessen the clutter.
fields.summary: Add a category to the Project list

fields.description: If a review participation is corrupted such that it contains a null user, then review indexing will fail and some reviews will not appear on the review dashboard, and review counts will be incorrect.
fields.summary: A null review participant causes review indexing to fail partway through the set of reviews

fields.description:
We're currently trying to find a stash/crucible workflow with defined review points. We don't want to review on a commit base. The idea was to use a merge commit as the single start point of a review. What I'm trying to achieve

A developer commits locally to a task branch
From time to time the changes are pushed to the developers "private" remote repository
After everything is finished the developer integrates his changes into a release branch in his "private" remote repository. The developers release branch will be pulled and pushed by a different person to a stable remote repository if all developer changes are integrated and working

The issue is that the push to the stable remote repository shows up in Crucible but with no changes attached to it. Stash displays the changes as expected inside the pushed merge commit.
fields.summary: Investigate why some merge changesets are empty in Crucible

fields.description:
Looks like a bug with WebDriver... 
https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/CRUCHG-JAVA7-SETUP-412
fields.summary: Setup Func Tests are failing under JDK 1.7

fields.description:
Crucible notifications are confusing as people can think that the author of a modification in a review is the author of a changeset as shown by the example below:
---------------
From the Crucible notification:
A revision has been added to Delta-67
•	xt/trunk/src/com/silverpop/xt/manager/NotificationProducer.java 
o	199242 by Tonja Kim

From Fisheye:
changeset 199242
Author: Rich Norris

Suspect this behavior is related to using batch mode for the File revision added notification events.
---------------

We should change the Crucible message to:

Tonja Kim added a revision to Delta-67
•	xt/trunk/src/com/silverpop/xt/manager/NotificationProducer.java 
o	199242 by Rich Norris
fields.summary: Clarify the notification message from Crucible

fields.description: {{DetailedReviewData.getReviewers()}} returns {{ReviewerData}} instances which contain time spent, but the author and moderator are returned just as {{UserData}} which doesn't contain their time spent.
fields.summary: Crucible API doesn't supply 'time spent' for author or moderator

fields.summary: Display month in a literal format for the due date

fields.description:
Quite a few people have reported that their comment is being auto-saved exactly at the moment they wish to post the comment.

{quote}
Wes ()
7:29 PM
I swear to god someone bound autosave of crucible comments to the tab key.
Wes ()
7:31 PM
`typing typing typing` - *tabs to save* - CHILL THE FUCK OUT WE'RE AUTO SAVING FOR YOU - … - … - …… - Okay, you can save now
{quote}
fields.summary: Investigate why Crucible seems to auto-save always exactly when you go to post a comment.

fields.description: (U) For crucible code reviews, it would be nice to have syntax highlighting for verilog, systemverilog and VHDL source code files.
fields.summary: Add syntax highlighting for Verilog, SystemVerilog, and VHDL

fields.description:
When doing a code review, reviewers can create defects.  However, there is no way to mark the defect as being handled without the original reviewer can go back and edit the comment and remove the defect.  It should be possible for the author and/or the moderator to mark a defect as handled.  

It would also be great if an author/moderator could see both a count of the number of defects as well as the number that still need to be handled, as well as a way to navigate through defects which have yet to be handled.  That way, an author can go through the review, fixing defects, and be able to easily tell if all of the defects have been fixed or handled in some other manner).

Currently, our solution is posting a 'handled' comment after every defect, and then walking through all the files/comments to make sure a 'handled' has been applied to every defect before closing the review.

It would also be nice to be able to select a categorization for how a defect was handled (fixed, entered in error, fix in future, issue created, decided against change, etc.).  I would assume this would be configurable just like  defect classifications.

There have also been a number of comments made at https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE/Flagging+Defects that indicate a desire for this feature.
fields.summary: Be able to mark Defects as Handled

fields.description:
You can reproduce the problem.

Create a branch.
Create a review.
Add code from the branch to the review.
Obliterate the branch.
Navigate away then back to the review.
You will see you cannot open the review.

It would be better to let the review continue but maybe show files/directories that were deleted.
fields.summary: You cannot view a review when you obliterate a branch in p4 that has files in the review

fields.description: Making review in IE8 and IE9 which are supported by Atlassian is extremely slow. Browser hangs while loading files, especially large .js (one example of that file attached) and it's geting work slower and slower while loading content of next files in current review. This is unnacceptable, IE shouldn't be on supported browser list for Crucible, because it's unusable.
fields.summary: Review performance in IE is pathetic

fields.description:
It is nice that you can create a Code Snipit and the "Copy" button shows up so that you can copy source out of the Code Snipit to the clipboard.

The Code Review does not support the "Copy" button. It would be nice to have the same funcationality to copy from a code review to the clipboard.

If I select the code out of the review and copy it to the clipboard there is a lot of extra formatting.
fields.summary: Copy source from a review

fields.description:
Crucible sends large cookies for UI preferences.  The default limit HEAD request size for the Jetty web server used by crucible is 4096 bytes.  As the cookies include a list of every open review the user has edit privileges on, this list could grow to be quite large.
The cookie holding the list of open reviews is called "editReviewShown" and "editReviewDetailsShown".
These are not cleared in Chrome, say when the "Continue where I left off" setting is set.

Modern browser usage is for long running browser sessions, especially with that option set.


*We should simply limit the length of review keys in these Cookies to 20 or so. And remove them in a FIFO order*

Examine if we need to be sending these or if we could perhaps take a different approach.  Look at what limits this imposes on crucible usage (max open reviews at once?).

Examine if we should increase the default we use for jetty to, say, 16kb.

There is a [documentation page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Setting+JVM+System+Properties] which describes how to adjust this limit.
fields.summary: Crucible sends cookies for UI preferences that can end up larger than the small Jetty default of 4096, consider alternative approaches to sending UI preferences and consider increasing the Jetty default

fields.description:
Hi folks.

Most developers in our group want to turn full diff context on in Crucible. However, if the file is particularly large, especially between code changes, there isn't an easy way to navigate up or down to the previous or next change if you aren't near a current difference in code. The proposed solution is two fold, first is to make the navigation arrows floating such that you can navigate using them without being near a code difference. The other change would be to map those arrows to keyboard shortcuts. This is so you could move up or down based on a keystroke instead.

Thank you in advance.

Cheers,
*Douglas Fabretti*
*Atlassian Support*
fields.summary: Would like improved navigation between code changes

review1_.cru_default_source as cru4_16_, 
review1_.cru_state as cru5_16_, 
review1_.cru_description as cru6_16_, 
review1_.cru_summary as cru7_16_,

fields.description:
I came across Gerrit Code Review recently and loved the idea. Sadly is only for it repositories. Mercurial support shouldn't be too different. Subversion is still possible but seems pretty hard on CVS.

I've been able to use a plug-in with SVN hooks, but the Gerrit Code Review looks to me like an stronger approach.
fields.summary: Implement feature like Gerrit Code Review but for all repositories

fields.summary: Update supported platforms now that Clearcase is no longer supported

fields.description:
Using the following XML for the "patch" REST API, notice that the last line does not contain a "curly bracket":
{code}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<addPatch>
   <patch>
<![CDATA[
Index: trunk/successBuild/src/test/java/PassingTest.java
===================================================================
diff -u -N -r171536 -r171537
--- trunk/successBuild/src/test/java/PassingTest.java	(.../PassingTest.java)	(revision 171536)
+++ trunk/successBuild/src/test/java/PassingTest.java	(.../PassingTest.java)	(revision 171537)
@@ -1,5 +1,6 @@
 //adsddada
 //dsjhfdskf
+//hdsjhfdkfh
 import junit.framework.TestCase;
 
 public class PassingTest extends TestCase
]]>   </patch>
   <anchor>
     <anchorPath></anchorPath>
     <anchorRepository>success</anchorRepository>
     <stripCount>0</stripCount>
   </anchor>
</addPatch>
{code}
Once the XML is posted to the API, the content will be added correctly to the review, however, the last line of the patch will be joined with the next line that is not in the patch:

!diff.jpg!

Command:
{code}
curl -v -s -u user:pwd -H "Content-Type: application/xml" -X POST http://localhost:8060/rest-service/reviews-v1/CR-3/patch --data-binary @- < patch.xml
{code}
fields.summary: "patch" REST API unites last lines of an attached patch

fields.description:
I push to the central repo, then immediately want to add the commit to my review.  I have to keep hitting "Later changesets", "Earlier changeset", "Later changesets"...and so on to keep refreshing the page until FishEye has finally indexed my commit a minute later.

Would be nice if we could add a button to force an incremental index and reload the changeset list immediately.  Would be fine to throttle it so it's not abused to DOS the server or anything.
fields.summary: Allow users to trigger an incremental index when creating a review

fields.description:
Only if the recipient is not already joined the review.
Also, if the user has no permission to view the review, "do something sensible"(TM).
fields.summary: Add a Join Review link to Shares and Mentions emails

fields.description:
When adding a crucible project, the "administrative" user needs read access to the fisheye repository itself (typically via "fisheye-administrator" group")

If "admin user" is not entitled in any group with at least read permissions for the repository, you can't select it from the list and therfor are not able to set the correct "default repository" for the new Crucible project.
fields.summary: Set default repository needs read access for fisheye-administrator

fields.description: Not sure if this was ever implemented in an old FeCru version, but it would be nice if the Dashboard activity could auto refresh like it does in JIRA.  Perhaps an option to do this if there's too  much of a performance issue with an instance but not in another.
fields.summary: Auto refresh of the Activity Stream

fields.description:
When Creating Jira Issues From a Code Review Provide Capability to Handle REQUIRED Fields.

In our FECRU instance we link to Jira. We have enabled the ability to generate Jira subtasks for a Crucible code review. It works, but the ONLY way we could make it work is for the Jira projects Field config to make all fields optional except for the standard mandatory fields that must be entered (i.e. Summary, Reporter, etc). Most production Jira instances have projects with Required fields.

Being able to create Jira issues from code reviews is an important feature for us but it MUSt be able to better handle  Jira projects with Required fields.

Please see my prior Support Case here : https://support.atlassian.com/browse/FSH-9162?focusedCommentId=2643178#comment-2643178
fields.summary: When Creating Jira Issues From a Code Review Provide Capability to Handle REQUIRED Fields

fields.description:
It would be beneficial to setup automatic code reviewers in a project. Instead of suggesting a reviewer based on whether they have modified a file before, there could be a group of reviewers for a project that are selected by some criterion (round robin, random, number of outstanding reviews, etc).

Using this approach will more evenly distribute the work load among project members so that some developers don't become swamped with reviews.
fields.summary: Automatically assign reviewers from a group

There may be more required to reproduce this.  I had 4 files in the review, 3 with comments.  Deleted comments from all, and was able to delete the one without any comments and one other.  But two of the files can't be deleted because they supposedly still have comments.
https://studio.atlassian.com/source/cru/CR-AJS-438#CFR-100233

Currently seeing this on Studio - but it's a backend problem so I doubt that is related.

fields.description:
- Create a Crucible project.
- Modify its View permission:
-- Not allowed for "Anonymous users"
-- Not allowed for "All logged in users"
-- Individual users = <adminuser>
-- Review Role = Reviewer
- Login as <adminuser> and create a review.
Add <reviewuser> as Reviewer.
- Verify that <reviewuser> has access to the default repo associated with the Crucible project.
- Login as <reviewuser> and try to view the just created review.

fields.description:
Seen on https://extranet.atlassian.com/crucible/cru/CR-STASH-1378

Seems to happen when I try to remove certain files from the review (these files usually have 5+ revisions in the review). 

A modal dialog appears with the following error (or similar)

{code}
Internal Server Error

An org.hibernate.exception.ConstraintViolationException was encountered

could not delete: [com.cenqua.crucible.model.FileRevisionExtraInfo#88099]
The DELETE statement conflicted with the REFERENCE constraint "FKD3011B4773591D1A". The conflict occurred in database "crucible", table "dbo.cru_frx_revision", column 'cru_frx_id'.
{code}

A workaround seems to be to remove each revision from the "train tracks" individually. This eventually removes the file from the review without error.
fields.summary: Removing files from review fails with ConstraintViolationException

fields.description:
If I use a "smart commit" message to start a review, it works fine when I first push the commit (using git). However, if I then later cherry-pick that commit into another branch and push that, it starts another review.

Steps to reproduce:

git branch my-feature-branch
git checkout my-feature-branch
... hack some code ...
git commit -m 'Implementing new feature. +review @bob @jim' -a
git push origin my-feature-branch

(review is created)

git checkout master
git cherry-pick <hash of above commit>
git push origin master

(second review is created)
fields.summary: Smart commits are re-triggered when cherry-picked to a different branch
